text:
Back in September, the @ObserverUK reported a huge overspend in children's services of more than £800m for the year. This is not going away.

Story here: https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/sep/01/children-social-care-services-councils-austerity …
author: michaelsavage

text:
But food for thought for campaigners - the NAO found no evidence that closing children’s centres led to increase in cases where the council had to step in.

Local authorities which closed children’s centres have not had any consequential increases in child protection plans.

5/6
author: michaelsavage

text:
The cost of children in care is rising. 

Local authorities are budgeting to spend £4.2bn on looked-after children in 2018-19, which is £350m (9.1%) more than they budgeted to spend in 2017-18.

Demand for residential placements and staff has outstripped capacity.

4/6
author: michaelsavage

text:
The most expensive cases, where children are taken into care, have risen by almost triple the rate of population growth.

Between 2010-11 and 2017-18 the number of children in care at year end increased by 15% to 75,420 children.

3/6
author: michaelsavage

text:
Councils have prioritised child protection work and reduced spending on preventative services. 

Proportion of spending on preventative services, such as children’s centres, fell from 41% in 2010-11 to 25% in 2017-18. 

Spending on statutory activities rose from 59% to 75%. 2/6
author: michaelsavage

text:
The terrific @NAOorguk has today reported on one of the crises in plain sight - children's social care.

Some bleak findings in the NAO’s report. 

Brief THREAD (non-Brexit, so I feel less bad): 1/6

text:
And they are buying back homes at high prices.

In Ealing, the council has spent £107m buying back 516 former council properties that it had originally sold for £16m.

That’s more than six times what they sold them for. 5/n
author: michaelsavage

text:
But get this...

There are 2,333 right-to-buy properties where the council now pays private landlords to house homeless families in London. 

Councils have spent £22m a year on this rent.

That’s right - renting back their old houses, at higher cost, to house the homeless. 4/n
author: michaelsavage

text: Around 466 individuals or companies have the leasehold for at least five former council homes each.  3/n
author: michaelsavage

text:
Properties are increasingly ending up in the hands of private landlords - with higher rents and less secure tenancies.

42% of homes  sold under the scheme in London are now rented out by private landlords, up from 36% in 2014. 2/n
author: michaelsavage

text:
THREAD on one of the issues that Brexit is masking.

The housing crisis. 

Yes, it’s still there - and a new #FOI analysis has highlighted some of the mad side effects of the Right-to-Buy policy, that allows council houses to be bought at a discount. 1/n

text:
After feeling stung over assurances that failed to hold water, ministers believe they have secured agreement that they will have legal advice about the wording of the Deal On Offer before they sign up.

Huge power then to attorney general and conference darling, Geoffrey Cox.
author: michaelsavage

text:
Having again been blindsided this week on a longer transition, I’m told senior ministers are now clear that they cannot vote for May’s Brexit Deal without a legal “break clause”.

This clause would stop the Irish backstop holding the NI/all of UK in the EU’s customs union.
author: michaelsavage

text:
*** Cabinet resignations are bad, but there is possibly a worse snag for May ahead ***

A little thread about how May could have been outmaneuvered by her own cabinet - and the possible consequences. It involves this man (the one on the right):

text:
Also... 

The real focus now senior figures are putting on the parliamentary end feels to me like a sign that many lost it with No10 this week.

There's been a shift - the Commons equivalent of a “You don’t know what you’re doing” chant faced by a failing football boss. Big week.
author: michaelsavage

text:
There are obvious pitfalls. What if there’s a majority for no option? 

True, but so say advocates: “Parliament could vote every option down, but I see no alternative to that.”
author: michaelsavage

text:
One idea is now being explored with Commons clerks...

If Deal is voted down, parliament should be presented with all the workable options (Norway/Canada/People’s Vote?) to test what there is a majority for. What theatre!

The model is the options vote Blair used on Lords reform.
author: michaelsavage

text:
There's been an “air of unreality”, says one Tory, because so much has focused on what May can get past her cabinet, rather than what would get through parliament.

If The Deal is voted down, how is a No Deal avoided given there’s no time left? 

That’s the essay question here.
author: michaelsavage

text:
*** Senior Tories drawing up a plan to let MPs vote for their favoured Brexit outcome ***

A thread (sorry) about one plan being cooked up by influential MPs desperate to avoid a “No Deal” Brexit should May’s deal be voted down.

Their answer - a Brexit Options Vote.

... the EU could say that the UK cannot frame the backstop to suit itself, but can extend the transition period.

That would mean - UK inside CU/single market - WITH free movement and cash.

That would anger Brexiteers, but seems an obvious riposte if EU wants to play hard ball.
author: michaelsavage

text:
These are the EU's options, as I see it....

- reject UK-wide backstop (problem - that means pushing the idea of an Irish sSea border & interfering in a country's constitution)

- accept it (huge cherry-picking issue)

- demand changes... the most obvious being...
author: michaelsavage

text:
So the EU's willingness to help solve the Irish border issue has opened up this "cherry picking" route it always said was impossible. 

So... a huge amount now hangs on how the EU responds
author: michaelsavage

text:
The problem is...

In applying the "backstop" to the UK as a whole, the UK may have (thru sheer unintended consequences and luck) put itself on course for decent Brexit outcome - customs union, bits of single market, no free movement, no paying in to the pot.
